snippet.title: Quickest v slowest cars of every brand RANKED!
snippet.description:
Change your car with Carwow: https://bit.ly/Change-Your-Car-0206

Have you ever wondered which are the quickest and slowest cars from each manufacturer? Well, wonder no more! 

We’ve pulled together a list of every manufacturer, and we’ve looked through cars they currently have on sale to see which has the largest gap between their quickest and slowest car currently on sale. 

There are a couple of rules for this list. For starters, the manufacturer must sell at least two models, and the cars need to be actually available to buy—sold-out cars are ruled out! 

What’s more, the cars need to be able to accelerate up to 62mph, and any commercial, pick-up truck and van-based MPVs are ruled out! 

Given this criteria, it’s no surprise to find supercars such as McLaren and Lamborghini ranked quite low in this list. After all, all the cars they manufacture are quick! But can you guess which will take the top spot?  Let us know in the comments!

snippet.title: Guess the car! 🚗
Ferrari SF90 v 1,000hp Golf R & BMW M240i: DRAG RACE
snippet.description:
Change your car with Carwow: https://bit.ly/Change-Your-Car-2905

It’s time for a tuned car vs supercar drag race! 

We’ve once again got our hands on the almighty Ferrari SF90, and it’s going up against a VW Golf R & a BMW M240i! But of course, the VW and BMW are able to put down a serious amount of power! Let’s take a closer look at the stats. 

First up, we have the Golf R. The original engine has been ripped out and replaced with a 2.5-litre 5-cylinder turbo from an RS3! This has been worked on further, and it now produces 1,048hp and 1,114Nm! Power is sent to all four wheels via a 7-speed DCT auto gearbox, and all in, it costs around £100,000! 

Next up, we have the M240i. As with the stock car, it’s packing a 3-litre 6-cylinder turbo, but the engine has been fully built, and it now puts down 1,014hp and 1,100Nm! This power is sent to all four wheels via an 8-speed auto, and all in, it costs around £85,000. 

As for the SF90, it’s equipped with a 4-litre twin-turbo V8 as well as three electric motors! These combine to produce 1,000hp and 800Nm, with power sent to all four wheels via an 8-speed dual-clutch gearbox. The car weighs 1,770kg, and it’s valued at an eye-watering £550,000!

So what do you think - can a Golf R & M240i take down an SF90?! There’s only one way to find out… LET’S RACE!

Subscribe to Carwow Drags:  @Carwow-Drags

snippet.title: This car has SO many cameras! 📸📸📸
The new BMW M2 CS got us like 😍🥵🚨
Is this Honda pretending to be a BMW?!
New BMW M2 CS & the BEST new cars coming 2025 - 2027!
snippet.description:
Change your car with Carwow: https://bit.ly/Change-Your-Car-2805

Say hello to the all-new BMW M2 CS! 

It’s the most hardcore edition of BMW’s all-new M2, and the BMW M team have gone to town to ensure the new M2 CS stands out over the regular car. So let's take a closer look at what's changed.

For starters, the kidney grilles, bumper, and front splitter have all been redesigned. Unfortunately, the headlights aren’t gold like those of other CS cars, but we’re not complaining too much—they still look fantastic! 

Along the side of the car, there are all-new bronze alloys, red brake callipers, and the option to add carbon ceramic brakes… Although they are an £8,000+ option! Around the back, there’s an absolutely massive ducktail spoiler, as well as a carbon fibre diffuser. The roof is also carbon fibre, which comes as standard on the CS. 

The layout of the interior is similar to the regular car, although there is now loads of carbon fibre to be found, coupled with a load of CS badges. The chassis has also been reworked to make it much more track-focused, and it comes with stiffer suspension than the standard M2. 

In terms of performance, the M2 CS has the same 3-litre twin-turbo straight-six as the regular car, but power output has increased from 480hp & 600Nm to 530hp & 650Nm respectively. It’s rear-wheel drive, only available as an automatic, and will cost around £86,000. 

BUT, that’s not all! There are a load of other new exciting cars on the horizon, from Ferrari, Mercedes and even Porsche! To find out what they are, stick around for this whole video to see what else is currently in the works!

snippet.title: Out of context Carwow...
Porsche 911 Hybrid v BMW M8 Comp: DRAG RACE
snippet.description:
Change your car with Carwow: https://bit.ly/Change-Your-Car-27-05

It’s time for an epic German head-to-head! 

We’ve got our hands on the BMW M8 Competition, and it’s going up against the new Porsche 911 Carrera GTS! Let’s take a closer look at our contenders… 

Starting with the Porsche, it’s powered by a 3.6-litre turbocharged flat-six that delivers 541hp and 610Nm of torque. This power is sent to all four wheels via an 8-speed auto, and it tips the scales at 1,645kg. As new, it costs around £139,100.

The M8 Competition is powered by a 4.4-litre twin-turbo V8, and this puts down 625hp and 750Nm. As with the M4, power is sent to all four wheels via an 8-speed auto, and it weighs in at 1,975kg. A new one of these will set you back £137,000.

So the BMW has more power, but could the hefty weight difference lead to the 911 snatching the win?! There’s only one way to find out for sure… LET’S RACE!

snippet.title: 911 GT3 RS v AMG GT R: DRAG RACE
snippet.description:
Get 20% off Car Vertical using code Carwow: https://bit.ly/Carwow-Car-Vertical

We'd like to say a huge thank you to the Al Ain Municipality (https://www.instagram.com/alainmun) and Tilal Swaihan (https://www.instagram.com/tilalswaihan) for providing the amazing drag strip, built to the highest standards to ensure safe racing and car proving away from the public roads.

Thanks, too, goes to Super Cars Majlis (https://www.instagram.com/supercarsmajlis) for inviting its amazing members along and providing the cars you see in our videos.

Also, a massive thanks goes to Ryan Griffiths at Syvecs (https://www.instagram.com/ryansyvecs) for his help in organising these races!

…………………………………………………………………………………………

It’s time for a supercar showdown! 

We’ve got Mat in the 992 GT3 RS, and he’s going up against racing driver Sam in the Mercedes-AMG GT R! But which will come out on top over the quarter-mile? Let’s take a closer look at the stats. 

Starting with the Porsche, it’s powered by a 4-litre naturally-aspirated flat-six that can produce 525hp and 465Nm of torque. This power is sent to the rear wheels via a 7-speed dual-clutch gearbox, and the car tips the scales at 1,450kg. It has a price tag of £192,600. 

As for the AMG, it’s powered by a 4-litre twin-turbo V8 which creates 585hp and 700Nm. This power is sent to the rear wheels only via a 7-speed auto gearbox, and it weighs in at 1,555kg. When this was new, it cost £156,000. 

This one’s going to be close! But can you pick a winner? There’s only one way to find out what will happen… LET’S RACE!

snippet.title: Chat, is this real?!
Has Volvo finally nailed it?
snippet.description:
Change your car with Carwow: https://bit.ly/Change-Your-Car-2205

This is the new Volvo XC90! 

It’s the second facelift this version of the XC90 has received, having originally been released way back in 2015! The question is, how much has changed compared to the two previous iterations? And is it still one of the best 7-seaters around? Mat’s about to take a closer look and find out. 

In terms of the design, there are a few updates over the previous edition. Up front, there’s a new bumper, a redesigned grille, and some updated headlights. Along the side, it’s pretty much the same as it was before, although that’s no surprise given the body panels have been retained from the previous edition. Around the back, the car is still almost identical to before, although options are fairly limited anyway when you’re a big seven-seat SUV! 

On the inside, there are a few notable changes. The infotainment screen now sticks out from the dash, and the operating system has been updated to Android Auto. The cabin is covered in soft-touch materials, and the general layout is still relatively the same as before. The digital dial screen has been retained, although it’s quite dark - competitors like the Audi Q7 certainly do it better. 

Regarding engines, there are only two to choose from. Both are 2-litre 4-cylinders, with the entry-level coming with a mild hybrid set-up that delivers 250hp. A plug-in hybrid option is also available, which adds a bigger motor and helps to produce 455hp. Both setups come with all-wheel drive and an 8-speed automatic gearbox. 

The new XC90 certainly looks the part, but it doesn’t come cheap! The entry-level starts from £65,000, with the range-topper (the car we have for this video) costs around £78,000. So is it worth it? Stick with Mat to take a closer look! 

Mat’s Volvo XC90 choice: https://bit.ly/Mats-XC90-Choice-2025

Land Rover Defender review: https://bit.ly/LR-Defender-Review

Audi SQ7 review: https://bit.ly/Audi-Q7-Review-2025

snippet.title: New Nissan Micra revealed!
Every Ariel Atom DRAG RACE
snippet.description:
Change your car with Carwow: https://bit.ly/Change-Your-Car-2005

It’s time for an Ariel Atom showdown!! 

We’ve got our hands on all four generations of Ariel Atom, and they’re about to go head-to-head over the quarter-mile! The question is, how much has this track-focused legend progressed? Let’s find out. 

Starting with the original Atom 1, it’s powered by a 1.8-litre NA 4-cylinder that produces 120hp and 145Nm. This is sent to the rear wheels via a 5-speed manual, and it only weighs 456kg! These days it’ll cost around £25,000. 

Next up is the Atom 2. It has a 2-litre supercharged 4-cylinder that puts down 300hp and 259Nm. Power is sent to the rear via a 6-speed manual, and it tips the scales at 496kg. In 2025, it’ll cost around £40,000. 

Alongside it, we have the 3.5-R. It’s also powered by a 2-litre supercharged 4-cylinder, but in this instance it creates 355hp and 330Nm. This is sent to the rear wheels via a 6-speed sequential, and it tips the scales at 550kg. As new, it costs £80,000. 

Then finally we have the latest edition, the 4R. It rolls up with a 2-litre turbocharged 4-cylinder, and it creates  406hp and 500Nm. It has rear wheel drive, a 6-speed sequential, and it tips the scales at 665kg. As new, it costs an eye-watering £140,000! 

So will it be a walkover for the 4R? Or could one of the older, lighter models spring a surprise? There’s only one way to find out… LET’S RACE!

Subscribe to Carwow Drags: @Carwow-Drags 

Mat’s performance car choice: https://bit.ly/Mats-Choice-2005

Supercar vs VW Beetle drag race: https://bit.ly/Drag-Race-2005

Thanks to @ArielMotorCompany for helping to set up this race!

snippet.title: This van can weigh itself! 😱
New Skoda Elroq Review
snippet.description:
Change your car with Carwow: https://bit.ly/Change-Your-Car-1905

Meet the Skoda Elroq! 

It’s an all-new mid-sized electric SUV, and it’s meant to compete with class leaders such as the Kia EV3 and Hyundai Kona Electric. The question is, should the Elroq be at the top of your shopping list if you’re in the market for a car such as this? Let’s take a closer look. 

Regarding the design, the Elroq looks pretty stylish on the outside. Given it’s electric there’s no grille at the front but the split DRLs and headlights help give it presence, as do the grooves on the bonnet. Along the side the satin roof bars stand out to help give it some definition, while around the back it’s all pretty standard, but then again that’s no bad thing! 

Step inside and you might be surprised by how much room there is, especially for passengers in the back! Up front, the majority of the cabin is covered in soft-touch materials, and there’s a large infotainment screen on the dash. Unfortunately, the climate controls are managed through the screen, but at least the system is pretty responsive. There’s loads of storage to be found, and there’s also a digital driver display, although it’s relatively small. 

There are a couple of models available in the Elroq range. It kicks off with the Elroq 50, which is equipped with a single motor for 170hp, a 52kWh battery, and a claimed range of 232 miles. The model we’re reviewing here is the 85, which has a 77kWh battery, a claimed range of 355 miles, and a single motor.

The entry-level Elroq is priced from £31,510, rising up to around £40,000 for the top-of-the-range edition. So is it worth it? You’ll need to stick with Mat to see for yourself!

Mat’s Elroq choice: https://bit.ly/Mats-Choice-1905

Check out Ask Mat: https://bit.ly/Ask-Mat-1905

snippet.title: 1,020hp M5 vs 1,000hp SF90 DRAG RACE! 🔥
Ford F-150 Raptor R v AMG G63: DRAG RACE
snippet.description:
Change your car with Carwow: https://bit.ly/Change-Your-Car-1605

Subscribe to Carwow Drags: @Carwow-Drags 

It’s time for a Germany vs USA showdown! 

We’ve got Mat in the incredible Mercedes-AMG G63, and it’s going up against the absolutely huge Ford F-150 Raptor R! So, can German power take down American power? Let’s check out the stats. 

The G63 is powered by a 4-litre twin-turbo V8 that produces 585hp and 850Nm of torque. Power is sent to all four wheels via a 9-speed automatic gearbox, and it tips the scales at 2,550kg. As new, it costs around £185,000. 

Next up, we have the F-150 Raptor R. It’s packing a 5.2-litre supercharged V8 that creates 720hp and 868Nm. Power is sent to all four wheels via a 10-speed auto, and it tips the scales at 2,699kg. If you’re looking to buy one in the UK, it’ll cost around £168,000. 

So will the extra weight prove to be the undoing of the F-150? There’s only one way to find out… LET’S RACE!

snippet.title: Lexus LX600 vs Nissan Patrol brake test!
Why the new Porsche Panamera is ALMOST perfect!
snippet.description:
Change your car with Carwow: https://bit.ly/Change-Your-Car-1505

This is the all-new Porsche Panamera! 

Mat’s got his hands on Porsche’s latest family-friendly cruiser to see what’s changed compared to its predecessors. What’s more, he’s also going to see if it has what it takes to go head-to-head against competitors like the Audi RS7. Let’s take a closer look… 

Starting with the design, this new generation of Panamera is easily the best-looking to date. Up front the design borrows elements from the latest Cayenne, has some smart creases along the bonnet, and any vents integrated into the bumper serve a real purpose. Along the side, proper door handles have replaced the pop-out ones from before, and the wide rear haunches give the car more presence on the road. The rear end has been slightly redesigned, but it’s still unmistakably a Panamera. All in, it looks seriously smart and sophisticated. 

The style and quality continue through to the interior as well. Soft-touch, high-quality materials throughout the cabin, and the infotainment screen is crisp, sharp, and responsive. The digital dials are customisable and bright, and there’s ample adjustment in the seats to offer the perfect view out. There may not be too much storage around the front of the cabin, but when you’re in a car this nice, does it really matter? 

The entry-level Panamera is powered by a 2.9-litre V6 turbo that produces 353hp and 500Nm. There are various pure ICE and hybrid models throughout the range, all the way up to the range-topping Panamera Turbo S e-Hybrid, which combines a 4-litre twin-turbo V8 and an electric motor to produce 782hp and 1,000Nm of torque! 

As for the price, the Panamera range kicks off from around £89,400. However, if you’re in the market for one of the V8-powered cars, this kicks off with the GTS, which starts from £131,700, rising all the way up to around £175,000 for the range-topping Turbo S e-Hybrid! So is it worth it? You’ll need to stick with Mat to see for yourself!

Audi RS7 review: https://bit.ly/Audi-RS7-Review-1505

Mat’s used Panamera deal: https://bit.ly/Mats-Used-Panamera-Deal-1505
